content.description: Start by mantling onto a mossy shelf. Then stem wide into the chimney, getting "creative" as it flares out near the top.
content.location: 12 ft to the right of Hanz Crack. The left wide stem box above the mossy shelf.

content.description: Creative stemming and lots of high steps and big reaches. This route is VERY finger size dependent. Bigger mitts might have a harder time reaching the top, while smaller fingers will excel.
content.protection:
Could be lead on several smaller pieces. .2-.4

Has top anchors. Also is the best rap station at the crag.
content.location: Near the middle of the crag, about 15 feet left of Measure of Pleasure.

content.description:
Thin seam just to the left of Hanz crack.   I think this is probably a TR only route as gear seemed pretty marginal. however if someone else can do this please let me know and i will update the page.  my partner and i both felt it started as a .9 and progressed to an .11 as you ascend. the last 10 feet are very blank. we both utilized the crack on the left to get through, but it kinda seemed like we were off route...

Super fun movement and a good mental challenge. I loved this climb
content.protection: if it takes gear it would be of the small variety, and a strong climber
content.location: small seam just to the left of Hanz crack.  there are 3 cracks in this area. according to the book the are rated (L-R) .10,.10+,.11. the one closest to Hanz crack seemed the most viable and is the .11

content.description: Follow parallel seams up the face, sticking to the right of center at first, then after a large horizontal crack move left.
content.protection: Bolts at the top shared with Hanz Crack, thin pro all the way up. X4's .1-.5   C3's 00-2
content.location: Just to the right of the prominent Hanz Crack.

content.description: Start up easy ledges (start of Nuggets) and then squeeze into the stem box. If the bottom section of the box was cleaned you could start straight up stemming probably... Mid section allows you to have some moves using the arête right/left. The final 2/3 is steeper and requires strenuous stemming.
content.protection: Pro up to 1". Easily found in the cracks to the left and right in the box if kept clean.
content.location: Look for a clean continual box between two really solid columns. To the left of Nuggets.

content.description: Start up the easy 5.7 climbing at the beginning, then fire up your boosters for a stiff finger crack to the top with a few opportunities for stems.
content.protection: Can be lead with plenty of smaller gear and one #4.
content.location: 10 ft to the right of The Measure of Please, on the other side of the tree and boulder.

content.description: Creative thinking and spacial awareness are necessary to reach the top. Thin edges and a lot of Newton's Third Law of Motion going on here.
content.location: South end of the crag. Look for the large orange section where the Rattler column recently fell.

content.description: Blocky column arete, some loose rock midway.  Hand jam crux near the top nearing 5.8 status.
content.protection: New anchors on face. Best anchors at the crag I think...
content.location: To the right of Sluice Box.

content.description:
Follow the thin crack on the right up to the hollow then reach left for the crux. After pulling through the roof, use the hand sized crack to the finish.

One of the best routes at the crag.
content.protection: Thinner pro at the beginning, great after the crux.
content.location: Far left, about 3 cracks to the left of Hanz.

content.description: A beautiful hand crack that has a couple of fun maneuvers to get you through the crux at the top. Certainly a must do for someone checking out the crag for the first time.

This is a pretty creative climb because is provides different challenges for climbers of different heights.  Those with shorter legs may find the crux at the top to be a little less annoying than those who may have longer legs.  A great climb for anyone who is looking to challenge themselves on something other than small finger cracks.

Fun, sporty movement to start, followed by some jugs in horizontal cracks to establish yourself in the steeper section of the route. Stem across the columns with tight fingers to the anchor.

NOTE: Name was referenced

by this comment

.
content.protection: Mostly small, thin gear though some larger stuff (hand/thin-hand) could be used in horizontals. Bolted anchor (no chains, only bolts) at the top.
content.location: Route to the climber's left of The Measure of Pleasure with shiny anchor bolts. Rappel The Measure of Pleasure.

content.description: This is a fantastic climb to get warmed up for the day.  What starts out as a wide fingers to small hands crack turns into a decent fists crack up at the top.  A little tougher than your normal 5.7.
Starts with a nice thin hands crack, moves through combinations of pressing and stemming with some fingertip jams in the back corners. Some edges and smearing on the outside corner faces.
content.protection: Some good protection at the bottom, but I think this is best top roped for now.
content.location: Start is to the right of a hanging block, with an obvious thin hand crack. From the top it's the easiest rappel, with a nice ledge to stand on just below the cliff edge.

content.description: Start on the freshly broken block. Reach/step high on your way up the fin. Avoid the crack on your left as you clip through the two bolts. Then jam up the hand crack to the top.
content.protection: Mixed pro. Two bolts, then a crack for mid sized pro.
content.location: 20 ft left of the Measure of Pleasure crack. The start is on a block that recently broke off.
